												At first coming from reflex, I hated this game with a passion. But after having over 2k hours on reflex over the years, it was time to look for something else. 1st impression, no feel for the bike, couldn't turn, coudln't whip, could barely make any of the jumps. And why is the camera panning sideways in 3rd person? This of all things really screwed me over, this panning of the camera sideways in every turn, made it very easy to run off the track in every turn. I felt limited it what I could do. Quit and played reflex some more, but the hours were wearing me down. Started playing Encore again when I heard KTM's were released as DLC. This time I gave it an honest try with an open mind, not allowing the sea of negativity to influence my opinion before I gave the game an real try. I would play to get to a point where I could get some clean laps in and start pushing, because this is where racing games come alive, when you are on the gas! The biggest difference for me between liking and hating this game, (other than the KTM's), was forgetting about 3rd person and playing in 1st person. After I started getting some basic lines down it really felt like Encore was designed to be played in 1st person, not 3rd. The game just felt so much more fluid in this view, much closer to what I've come to expect from an MX vs ATV game. Looked way better and played better as you feel the bike more as you actually have a feel for the front of the bike. 3rd person by comparison feels very, VERY stiff and static.


YouTube™ Video: Mx vs atv supercross   Seattle practice laps 

			Views: 234		



I came to realize that my initial opinion of the game was compounded by friends saying "don't play this game it sucks." It was also influenced by the fact that the supercorss was different from Reflex, which is what I was used to. When I first started reflex I hated it, why? because it didn't play like unleashed. And reflex turned out to be one of my most played games of all time. Also bear in mind that reviews from early access are not seperated. It was a totally different game back then, and a lot of gripes have been addressed.The tracks themselves offer a nice variety of content, though I do wish nordic would release the 2016 AMA supercross tracks which are all out there....somewhere. Not as much a fan of some of the outdoor tracks but they do offer a completly different challenge with those flat turns that require a completly different approach to how you attack the track. I do wish SX tracks would get rutted the same amount as outdoors though, Sounds are pretty well done, feels great when you open up the throttle, go though the whoops and rev the bike in the air.


YouTube™ Video: Mx vs ATV Supercross: Atlanta Track Preview 

			Views: 131		

			Track preview, AMA Supercross 2017 Atlanta. Recorded on PC. Music: Digital MK.2 by Tri-Tachyon		

At it's core this still is an MX vs ATV game. Lots of huge lines to be found, still feels great when you land the rythms clean and you put down a fast lap - Physics are pretty much on par with what you would expect with an Mx vs ATV game, not ultra realistic but not over the top arcadey. Feels like there is much more traction than reflex and the clutch will actually give you a decent boost. Unlike reflex, you actually have to use the clutch and brakes in encore, as you can very easily blow the turns. I do wish, however, that manual shifting was a little more refined so that there would be a real benifit to manually working your way though the gears instead of staying in 5th and using the clutch. That said automatic transmission works just as well and is what you would expect from an mx vs atv game without manual shifting. In the end I feel both are on par with eachother. Preloading can seem over the top in 3rd person as it seem like the bike gets popped up and launched forward, but I find it much more mellow playing in 1st person. In my videos above, I do preload quite a few jumps but you don't see that huge pop up and forward that you see in 3rd person.At this point, after hating encore for so long, I'm playing it a lot more. (but I still hate it's implemention of 3rd person which I think puts a lot of people off). Its not a perfect game, it still has it quirks and still could benifit from some elbow greese, but what game is perfect? So if you're thinking of trying this game, ignore the sea of negativity. Stop by my page and check out some of my videos and see for yourself how much fun this game can be. See you on the track racers!

												I think this game has gotten more hate than it deserves.  It is too often compared to Reflex, which was a fantastic game.  In terms of realism, I would agree that Reflex is the best game to this day.  However, this game targets a slightly different audience.  The objective here wasn't to have an ultra-realistic game that offers no forgiveness for messing up in a rhythm section.  The goal was to have a supercross game that gave players the sensation of realistic racing, while still allowing newer players to make small mistakes without throwing their entire race away.  There are more supercross tracks than Reflex, and the poor excuse for an upgrading system has been replaced.  The "physics" that everyone complains about are actually pretty good too.Bottom line:  If you're looking for a new supercross game that takes a certain amount of skill and knowledge about sx, but doesn't have simulator-level difficulty, I think you'll enjoy this game.Also, for anyone who says it's impossible to do a whip - it's possible; you just have to learn how.

												First off, before anything.... I KNOW IT"S ON PC BUT FOR THE LOVE OF GOD USE A CONTROLLER. Just trust me, the way the game's built it feels so much better that way.Okay now that that's been established... the actual gameplay.The Reflex system IS in this game, but if the last game you played was Reflex, well, it handles a little differently, so be prepared. The rider control influences the bike a lot more in turns, you can easily accidentally 180-360 degree turn your bike if you aren't careful. Other than that, the responsiveness is a lot better and feels a lot more like your rider has weight. It does make the physics system a little wonky if you ignore the rider control though, as the bike feels a lot more like a slippery brick, Rainbow has done a wonderful job of weighting these systems together and the rider and bike feel separate and together at the same time (unlike Reflex where they often felt more separate than anything else).Vehicle customization returns and changing off stock parts does change the performance of the bike/atv, although the fine tuning from Reflex is not there, (I'm very sad about this).The AI still crashes into you, but it won't throw you off your ride. It actually drives like it isn't trying to commit a murder suicide constantly, although the AI doesn't compensate for slipperiness on the ATVs so be prepared to see more than one com flying at you from another track section. Other than that, it's no more easy or difficult, you just won't be forcibly wiped out by the AI every 10 secs if you get stuck in the group.Your Bike is also more sturdy now, or at least it feels more sturdy (I've been told it's slipperry though if you don't pull back on the rider to increase traction), and wiping out isn't quite as easy unless you throw the bike and rider hard in one direction or ram your front wheel into the ground when landing. The actual Reflex (QTE to stay on the bike from Reflex game) is gone making some landings that seem like they should throw you off strange when they would have thrown the QTE to recover in your face before, you now have to recover (or break your riders neck) with your own decisions, the bike will not auto-recover via magical Analog stick flick anymore.And finally we also see the return of the 50cc class. That's random but it's so fun.Overall Score:Pros-  - The Reflex system, after a minor adjustment period, feels a lot better  - The core gameplay is still there, however it leans heavily on the reflex system rather than steering.  - Bike customization affects performance to a degree  - Your placement is still determined more by the lines you picked and your ability to control the bike than your ability to out run the AI with blind speed. In fact, blind speed will  lose the race a lot of the time, even on rookie.  - There are 34 tracks. 17 Supercross, 12 National, and 5 Rhythm   - You can wear a chicken mask as a helmetCons  - The Gameplay is a bit more nuanced and weighted towards the rider than before. As such it feels very clunky if you ignore the rider controls.   - Bike can feel slippery and underperforming to new players. This is fixed with parts which are unlocked during play easily.   - Fine tuning is goneOverall 7.5/10 It's good.

												Looks like after the recent update this game seems to be much better with my computer, usually getting a constant 60fps in SX and 30-45 in MX. I really do thank Rainbow for finally fixing the performane issues, so now I shall write a fair review in return. I'm gonna try and keep it short as possible, but looks like there's lots of things to cover here. I'm not trying to bash on Rainbow or Nordic in any way, just reviewing the game in my honest and opinion.First off, the game itself is kinda fun, but doesn't really live up to what i was expecting. I was honestly hoping for a reflex2.0, but it turned out as a washed out Alive2.0. To start here, the physics are honestly what i think are weighing down the rest of the game so much. I would have been fine if the same physics for reflex were used for supercross encore, because it really is the better of the motocross games out there. The new physics engine isn't terrible, but it feels like there was a step backwards from the right direction. The turning is like skating on brown ice simulator amped up a notch, and the whips are more like slightly maneuvering the bike sideways rather than flipping it which ever way you want like a sick pancake. scrubbing is alright but sometimes you'll end up turning sideways and transition into a super lame whip then proceed to land sideways because bringing back a whip is actually hard to do for some reason.Braking seems to be a problem too. i had a few times when i hit the brakes and spun into a 720 noscope as if i were playing mw2 quickscope battles on rust. i know i had the oversized brakes updgrade on but jeez dude i dont think they have that kind of power.Again, unlike reflex this game has your rider as a living tank that holds on to the bike with an absolute death grip and will only wreck if you are completely flatlining or upside down when landing a jump. Same with getting smacked into by other riders, instead of both wrecking, it just goes into bumper cars mode. and for the most part the AI is still dumb as it has been for generations now. most the time you can win a race going half speed as long as the opponents keep crashing into one another.This game also really abuses the use of the clutch and seatbouncing, it's over powered what you can do if you just pop the clutch(which would stall the bike) and then seatbounce off a triple, you'll end up quading into the next section from the super mega ultrasanic speed boost. also it'd be real sweet if there was a manual gear shifting option, because no full sized racing dirtbike i've ever seen is automatic.AND WHERE DID THE TRACK DEFORMATION GO?that was one of  the coolest features for reflex, because you could carve out your out deep ruts and really rail it around berms with em, but in sx encore it seems like you cant even put an indention into the ground, sadly. Also... the rider reflex thing that you can use to save yourself from a crash is absent from this game, it's just an automatic animation. why would you do that?so yeah it's apparent now that i really liked reflex, and lots of other mx vs atv fans can agree it's the best one out there.Now that the biggest problem  is out of the way, i can get onto the little details and stuff i noticed were missing.Ok, so the career mode isnt really much of a career, it's just racing after racing and getting some cool rewards, which is how it's been in pretty much all of the previous mx vs atv games. I'd like to see a career mode done differently, with sponsorships and all that fun stuff. You know another thing that's just completely missing from the supercross experience? where's all the qualifying, heats, semis, and lcq races? the race just starts off in the main event, which is really anticlimatic for me. Where's the 20 man gate drop too? i've been waiting around for that for years. This isnt much of a big deal, but it'd really add to the authenticity that makes this game "supercross".Sountrack is good for the most part with some cool fitting music, but there were some songs i felt kinda killed the mood for me. BUT i did hear some of the old reflex songs and i was really excited to hear those again because they are amazing.The customization is still nice with the variety of cool gears there are, but there's always gotta be more. Would be nice if there were even more added for free, or really really.... really cheapMost of the tracks out there are actually great and feel like a SX track. so that's one good thing going for the game if i may say. The addition of the MX tracks from alive is definitely great, and im sure glad it happened, so why not also add tracks from other games too? reflex, untamed, and unleashed all had some good stuff and i'd like to see em again. why not throw in some of the older gears too?also please dont make expensive dlc.  like seriosuly nobody likes that. if a company were to sell me dlc, it better be worth every pennyso im finally gonna wrap up this super long review. i didnt spend too much time organizing but i think i got my point across.best wishes to rainbow and nordic because i want to believe they can bring the series back to life. thanks to the developers again, but come on man you can surely do better, YOU JUST GOTTA BELIEVE!TLDR: game is fun, but it aint no reflex. i wanna recommend this game but i just cant do it."it's ok"6/10

												UPDATE: In all fairness to Rainbow Studios, I promised to update this review if it changed. The game does seem to be running better now. The SX still drops occasionally, but it is nowhere near as bad as before and not too noticeable.I played one National event, and,  while not as smooth as I'd like, it is now playable and if you can deal with a few drops here and there, not bad. But also, having played the game more now, I do have a few complaints. Let's be honest, the DLC is a money grab here. Sell me the whole game up front. I get adding on new tracks as time goes by, but these were tracks released  on the original XBOX 360 and PS3 games, not brand spanking new. And having to pay for a bike that the competitor offers as standard is getting a little old. However, it is still a fun game. I bring up these issues in hopes that one day the developer will listen and I won't have to keep playing the lottery hoping I can win in order to fund the motocross game I'd like...you know, the tracks from the Lucas Oil Nationals and better physics. I mean, come on, I haven't played Budds Creek since Jeremy McGrath Supercross on the N64. GIVE THE PLAYERS WHAT THEY WANT, but I digress. If you like motocross/supercross, you'll like this game....hopefully they'll come out with a great sequel. ORIGINAL REVIEW:I have to say I regret purchashing this game a little. I read the other reviews and said, "Maybe they're crazy and it runs just fine." And then I bought it and said "Nope, I am crazy for thinking it will be different." I have an NVIDIA GTX 960 with the game installed on a SSD and the frame rate drops are so horrible on the Nationals tracks that I can't stand to play it. The drops aren't too bad on Supercross style tracks, but it is annoying. Having said that, maybe if I upgrade my old AMD A6 processor and added more RAM, it might run better as I've noticed memory and CPU to be very,very high while running this game. Also, dropping some of the settings seems to have improved it a bit. Other newer games run just fine, so maybe this one is just not optimized for PC. I will say that the handling does seem to be improved from the XBOX 360 version. My rider no longer does 360s on the ground a lot and doesn't seem to cross jump like a goon all the time. Is it the same as MX Simulator? No. But honestly, I haven't fallen over in real life as much as my MX Sim guy, so take it as you will.  Is it the same as MXGP? Not really. The turning still doesn't feel as nice. But, you can throw way better whips....in that you can actually control a whip. If you all ready own it on 360 or PS3, it's probably a waste of your time, but I am lazy and don't feel like walking to the other side of the house to turn on my 360, so I have it on here. It's just the same game though, there's not really anything new for you. If you like motocross, well supercross, then it's a decent game, assuming you have an extremely powerful machine, maybe. I don't know, that frame rate thing could be present on all of them. Or I guess you could just wait for the May release of the Xbox One version and stream it to your PC. But I cannot honestly recommend it until it can be played without frame drops on a modest PC instead of a "Dude, I future-proofed the crap of my system" PC. I'll update this review if anything changes.

												I'm glad I took a chance and bought this (on sale), despite all of the negative reviews.  Basically, it feels like mx vs atv supercross on the 360/ps3, except they cleaned up the handling a bit (feels like I have some traction now) and threw in the motocross tracks from alive.  I love reflex, but the 90mph tracks and doing a forward or back flip off of a tuff block at 10-20mph really got old.  This game has some quirks for sure, but I'm enjoying it.  For example, as with the console version, there are rare phantom inputs that will steer me off course, or throw my rider way forward off a jump.  Also, I can really feel the loss of forward speed (like crazy wind resistance) in the air.  On the other hand, though, I like the tighter tracks (especially the outdoor tracks from alive), the fact that I actually need the brakes, and the handling in the turns.  The clutch is crazy op as others say, but I like that I can goof a turn and make up for it with that.As for the graphics, maybe some people are reviewing the game without launching the graphics settings program first (a seperate thing for some reason, just like reflex)?  I played at 4k and other than the inconsistent framerate and some lod popping, it looked just as good as reflex to me (even better in some places where texture resolution is higher and meshes have more detail).  I think rainbow/nordic REALLY need to force the settings program to launch before the first play, because the default settings look terrible, and leave a bad first impression.As a fan of the series since the first motocross madness, I would have preferred that rainbow just tighten up the tracks and ease up on the crash-if-someone-nudges-me physics in reflex to make a follow-up game (instead of completely changing the engine for alive/supercross), but I'm definitely not in agreement with the chorus of bad reviews this game is getting. 												So for someone who comes from the background of playing racing titles mainly made by Codemasters, & Milestone I didn't expect much for this game.Was I right? Simply put, no.This game from what it seems is a Remastered Edition of MX vs. ATV Supercross converted to run on Higher End Systems, or just to bring the game to life with a few nifty updates. That, said, this is my first visit with these titles and I'm pleasantly surprised by the game.It definitely fits into a niche crowd with people who just adore arcade style racers, people who wanna blow off time, and for others who are simply looking for an offroad game.It provides, with things like the ever so beloved AI who can never seem to decide what part of the track they wanna take, let alone if they want to be in a straight line they'd rather scope out their own trail for the course.It also maintains itself with an interesting take on outdoors style tracks, something the original version of the game didn't contain. It truly lets you filter your adventuring.Mixed racing, & other sorts to provide you with different style challenges, and learning to share a track with a quad-biker who just wants to try and cut your line off every time you catch him with his pants down.I personally jumped into this game wanting a different experience, and telling myself I'd never actually lay hands on this game.I EAT MY WORDS BIG TIME. I was in search of a game that gave me mixed racing, and just an over all fun time, nothing to be taken seriously.I can slightly copare this game to its younger brother MX vs. ATV Reflex as I bought it and played them side by side just to have more games to jump along and play.I will say the two handle nothing at all like each other, and if you want to grab it just be expecting a more light feeling bike, and looser ATV's that seem to get stuck in one direction when riding through the carved patterns of someone elses bike. Besides that, it doesn't get itself too lost and feels slightly like the MXGP Bikes, both ATV, & MX.Tricks, tracks, jumps, whips, all included. 												Update: Rainbow released an optimization update, the game now runs at around 60fps most of the time. It could use more but it's definately playable now.ORIGINAL REVIEW:MX vs. ATV is back. The question is, is it good?The answer is, kind of.MvA Supercross Encore (long enough title?) Is an updated version of 2014's Mva Supercross originally released on Xbox 360 and PS3. The game features updated visuals, rider gear, bikes, Nationals tracks from MvA Alive, and a new event called Rhythm Racing. The game also retains the tracks from the 2014 Supercross release. The handling of the bikes was very clearly overhauled since the release of the early access version, and you can actually whip bikes around quite a bit now. Leaning into turns was drastically changed, you're able to slide around a lot more than you could before. The tracks look nice and are fun to play. Now, why is this game 'kind of' good?The optimization is downright horrible. Really. On a GTX 680 and a Core i7, you'd think I could run this game no problem, that is NOT the case. Most tracks run at around 40-50 FPS, often dropping into the low 20s. I just can't get my head around why the optimization is so bad. Reflex had very good optimization and ran like a dream. This game, is sluggish at best, unfortunately. It really is a shame, as the new physics are actually pretty fun to play with.Honestly, with the optimization how bad it is right now, I simply cannot reccomend this game. Yes, the tracks are fun and flow well. Yes, the new features are really nice. But the optimization is really dragging it down and I hope it gets improved within reasonable time.
